    • PYTHON.ORG

This PEP proposes adding pattern matchingâ€”a sort of enhanced switch statementâ€”to the Python language. Read the PEP at the link above and follow the discussion on Reddit.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

def is_tuple(node: Node) -> bool:
    match node:
        case Node(children=[LParen(), RParen()]):
            return True
        case Node(children=[Leaf(value="("), Node(), Leaf(value=")")]):
            return True
        case _:
            return False

è¿™éå¸¸ Elixir äº†.

)

  • Clinging to Memory: Python å‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨å¦‚ä½•å¢åŠ å†…å­˜ä½¿ç”¨é‡
    • ITAMAR TURNER-TRAURING

One of the advantages Python has over a language like C is that you donâ€™t have to worry about how memeory is freed up during program execution. But sometimes Pythonâ€™s memory management doesnâ€™t work the way youâ€™d expect.

  • Pythonçš„ reduce(): ä»å®ç”¨é£æ ¼åˆ° Pythonic é£æ ¼

In this step-by-step tutorial, youâ€™ll learn how Pythonâ€™s reduce() works and how to use it effectively in your programs. Youâ€™ll also learn some more modern, efficient, and Pythonic ways to gently replace reduce() in your programs.
